cooked:
ZmnSCPxj:

Does it require all parties to be online simultaneously?

So to be clear about this (mostly for my own benefit, as I am a dilettante, with no true background in cryptographic math): for example, with MuSig2, you can have an external actuary who is NOT one of the parties interested, each of the actual interested parties can come online whenever, they do not have to be online simultaneously with each other, only with the actuary, and then hand over public keys. Then the actuary can calculate the address to be funded that is controlled by the MuSig2 combination, using the MuSig summation algorithm. The interested parties can be convinced that their own interests at least are encoded in that address, by the actuary providing the list of interested party pubkeys, then the individual interested party can double-check by checking that their own public key is included, and that the address is indeed the correct MuSig sum of the listed public keys.

In contrast, with FROST, there can be no actuary, each of the interested parties must be online simultaneously and send messages to each other, and each has to keep a share generated from the setup interaction. The setup must be simultaneously online.

With a covenant opcode like OP_CSFS, a third-party actuary can solicit the public keys of the interested parties, generate the SCRIPT embedding those public keys, and then use the MuSig combination of all interested party public keys to be used as the keyspend path key, and then generate a Taproot address with the SCRIPT embedded. The interested parties can double-check the address generated by the actuary and at least be assured that at least their own interest is encoded in the generated address.

This is relevant in e.g. LSP-client relationships, where a single LSP might want to use a single UTXO to back channels to many clients (i.e. SuperScalar technique). The clients may be mobile devices, where you have the chance of a fireball in hell that all of them will be online simultaneously, thus setup without simultaneous-onlineness is a requirement. The LSP takes on the role of actuary, and funds the UTXO, and the client comes online later, double-checks that ther interest is encoded in the confirmed onchain UTXO, then does exchanges of preimages for coins indirectly funded from the confirmed onchain UTXO.

I think the “arbitrary spending condition” goal is a mistake: any sufficiently complicated program is indistinguishable from a buggy program, and thus “arbitrary spending condition” is a laughable goal, once this insight is realized. The REAL goal is “trustless non-simultaneously-online setup”; we can already set up practical vaults using pre-signed transactions, but they require all interested parties to be simultaneously online during seteup.
